items.title: Googleâ€™s Gemini is about to make its home appliance debut
items.summary: Gemini is headed to Samsung's new Family Hub refrigerator and AI Wine Cellar.
items.body: Credit: Samsung TL;DR Samsung will launch new home appliances powered by Gemini at CES 2026. The AI chatbot is coming to Samsungâ€™s new Family Hub refrigerator to offer users a more convenient and personalized experience. The company will also showcase a Bespoke AI Wine Cellar with a Gemini-powered AI Vision system. Samsung is set to unveil its first-ever refrigerator powered by Google Gemini at CES 2026 . This is not just a first for Samsung, but also a milestone for Gemini. Until now, Googleâ€™s AI chatbot has lived inside phones, the web, and more recently Google Home speakers and displays . Samsungâ€™s upcoming home appliances will mark Geminiâ€™s debut in a major new category.

items.title: Samsungâ€™s wide foldable leak hints at a pre-emptive strike on Apple
items.summary: Looks like Apple's foldable iPhone will not get a clean debut as Samsung prepares for a head-on battle.
items.body: Credit: Paul Jones / Android Authority TL;DR Samsungâ€™s rumored â€œWide Foldâ€ is reportedly set to feature a tablet-like 4:3 inner display. The device could closely resemble Appleâ€™s rumored foldable iPhone in terms of size and shape. Unlike the tall Galaxy Z Fold 7, this model would prioritize stability and easier reading. Samsung is expected to launch it alongside its usual Fold, expanding its foldable lineup to three devices next year. The Wide Fold is also expected to feature 25W wireless charging. Samsung isnâ€™t done experimenting with foldable form factors. After launching the Galaxy Z TriFold , rumor has it that the company is working on another foldable phone design, a wide one to counter Appleâ€™s upcoming foldable iPhone. Now, a new report from South Koreaâ€™s ETNews has revealed more details about this new Samsung foldable and how it might compare to Appleâ€™s competing device.

items.title: How Rogers and Villa exposed Man Utd defence
items.summary: Match of the Day pundit Dion Dublin analyses what went wrong for Manchester United against Aston Villa, and Wayne Rooney discusses the World Cup potential of "man of the moment" Morgan Rogers.

items.title: Chelsea hammer nine goals past Liverpool in Women's League Cup
items.summary: Chelsea put nine past Liverpool in the Women's League Cup to progress to the semi-finals, as Sam Kerr scores the opening two goals and Johanna Rytting Kaneryd completes a hat-trick.

items.title: The best team today lost - Amorim
items.summary: Manchester United Manager Ruben Amorim says that Manchester United performed better despite losing 2-1 to Aston Villa.

items.title: Emery elated with 'fantastic' Aston Villa win
items.summary: Aston Villa manager Unai Emery praises his "fantastic" players in a hard-fought 2-1 win against Manchester United.

items.title: Stunning Rogers double secures Villa win over Man Utd
items.summary: Morgan Rogers scores twice for Aston Villa in their 2-1 win against Manchester United, extending Villa's unbeaten run to 10 matches in all competitions.

items.title: Before I knew it, ChatGPT went from a useful tool to time-wasting a habit
items.summary: AI became my new endless doom-scroll without me noticing.
items.body: Credit: Calvin Wankhede / Android Authority There are plenty of mixed opinions on AIâ€™s potential benefits and harms , but Iâ€™ll admit Iâ€™ve been somewhat hooked on it from day one. I tend to dive deep into subjects with AI for short bursts that might last hours or on-and-off for a few days, and then drift away for weeks or more when life gets busy with things that are obviously more important. Slowly but surely, though, I realized I was doing less and less when it came to other personal interests. While my AI use never disrupted my real-life obligations or relationships, it was starting to cannibalize my hobbies. Recently, I started scrolling through my massive ChatGPT log entries. Some were simple entertainment, and others were deep thoughts that frankly got a bit heavy. There were more interactions than Iâ€™d ever care to count. Thatâ€™s when the thought hit me: â€œHas this become my new doom scroll?â€ I started wondering how I got to that point, how much time I was wasting, and why it felt so addictive. Eventually, I took a deeper look at my AI usage patterns and then took a step back.

items.title: MCON is the first truly mobile controller that covers all of my gaming needs
items.summary: Finally, a mobile controller that actually fits in my bag.
items.body: Itâ€™s hard to believe that itâ€™s been more than two years since the sliding magnetic controller that we now know as MCON was introduced to the world in a YouTube video . At the time, it was heavily focused on the Apple ecosystem, but now that the device is finally out, itâ€™s turned into so much more. Sure, it still has MagSafe magnets, but now so do Pixel phones. Magnets on phones are here to stay, and MCON is one of the first gaming controllers trying to take advantage of them with a sliding design that calls back to the legendary PSP Go and Xperia Play.

items.title: The iPhone 16e proves that Apple will never beat Android at budget phones
items.summary: I'm a sucker for a good value, but this phone just makes me feel like a sucker.
items.body: At this point, thereâ€™s little doubt in my mind: Android will always rule the affordable smartphone game. Itâ€™s not because Apple hasnâ€™t tried, nor is it because every cheap Android phone is really that good, but rather because I donâ€™t think a cheap iPhone works anymore. At least, it doesnâ€™t work in the way that Apple keeps trying to present it. Put another way, the iPhone 16e is the least sensible phone of 2025, and Iâ€™m at a loss to understand why Apple thought it was a good idea. Iâ€™ve reviewed it alongside all of its closest Android rivals, and I think itâ€™s best served as a reminder that copying Apple isnâ€™t always a good idea. Hereâ€™s what I think it gets so wrong in the face of so many good Android options.

items.title: The best tech of 2025: Android Authorityâ€™s picks the top tablets, handhelds, foldables, and more!
items.summary: 2025 was another bumper year for tech, and these were the highlights.
items.body: Every year, we round up the best tech the year had to offer, and 2025 was among the best in recent memory. There was stiff competition across established technology categories, while new genres emerged and blossomed across the year. But which products truly set themselves apart from the rest? Below are the devices that are our top picks for the best tech of 2025.

items.title: Booze, beach, beaten - how England lost the Ashes
items.summary: BBC Sport chief cricket reporter Stephan Shemilt reveals the inside story of England's Ashes defeat in Australia on and off the pitch.
